dataset.title: The Effect of Vegetation and Habitat Type on Rodent Biodiversity in Mapungubwe National Park

abstract.para: The status of small mammal populations reflects ecosystem integrity. This study focused on rodent populations in two different habitats of the Mapungubwe National Park, the mopane savanna and riverine forest. Live trapping and vegetation surveys were performed in an effort to determine a relationship between rodent population presence and habitat structure. We found that there was a greater rodent abundance in the mopane savanna, but that there were no significant differences in diversity and richness between the two habitats. The higher abundance corresponded to areas with a greater understory height, lower soil penetrability, and closer proximity to major rock outcroppings. These findings establish that there is a relationship between habitat characteristics and rodent species abundance. This information can be used by conservationists as a baseline measure to develop conservation goals and plans that reflect the interconnected nature of ecosystems.

section.para: We conducted our study in the Mapungubwe National Park in the Limpopo
Province of South Africa. We utilized ten study sites: five in the riverine forest along the
Shashi River and five in the mopane savanna (Appendix 1). We set out ten Sherman
traps at each of our ten sites, putting out one hundred traps in total. Within each site, we
placed five traps under cover and five in the open. A trap placed under cover, or a closed
trap, was placed under tight vegetation, usually a shrub, whereas a trap placed in the open
might have been placed along a log or at the bottom of a tree (never totally in the open).
In addition, half of the traps were standard size (8 x 9 x 23 cm) and half were long traps
(8 x 9.5 x 30 cm). Slade et al. (1993) demonstrated that long traps had a consistently
greater capture rate than short traps, and thus are more effective. Due to resource
limitations, we were unable to use long traps exclusively. Instead, we used an equal
number of long and short traps at each site to ensure that there was an equivalent chance
of catching rodents at all sites.
For the safety of the animals that we caught, we made sure that all traps were
well-shaded by covering them with debris. We baited each trap with a mixture of peanut
butter, oats, and honey. We rebaited the traps after each catch and every afternoon, so as
to ensure bait freshness. We checked the traps once in the early morning (between
5:30am and 10:30am) and once in the late afternoon (between 3:30pm and 6:30pm) for
four consecutive days (Tuesday, 14 November, 2006-Friday, 18 November, 2006) in the
beginning of the summer rainy season. If we did find a specimen in one of our traps, we
adhered to a uniform catch procedure: We uniquely marked and then released the
specimen. We also recorded species weight and sex. We analyzed our collected data
using Excel, Statistica and Primer.
Vegetation/Habitat Survey
To see if there was any relationship between the specific rodent species present
and habitat conditions, we conducted habitat/vegetation surveys at each of our ten sites.
We walked two 50 meter transects at each site from North to South. The transects were
approximately ten meters apart. For each transect, we evaluated and recorded the habitat
type at one meter intervals: grass, sand, dirt, woody debris, dung, tree, rock, or shrub.
Every five meters, we also estimated the proximity to a major rock outcropping and
estimated the visibility at twenty centimeters, alternating to the East and to the West. In
order to measure the visibility, one researcher held their head twenty centimeters above
ground, while the other moved a notebook in a straight line away from the transect, also
twenty centimeters above ground. When the individual at twenty centimeters could only
see half of the notebook, we recorded the distance between the two individuals. These
measurements were taken with the purpose of determining the level of habitat appeal and
availability of protection from predators. Finally, every ten meters within each 50 meter
transect, we took a penetrometer measurement of the soil to get a sense of the level of
ease with which a rodent could burrow. Additionally, we noted the presence of dung,
woody debris, rocks, or live trees within one meter of each transect. We analyzed all data
with Excel, Statistica, and Primer.
